title: Egerton, Kent
text:
Egerton is a village and <a href="civil%20parish">civil parish</a> in the <a href="Ashford%20%28borough%29">Ashford</a> District of <a href="Kent">Kent</a>, England. The village is on the <a href="Sandstone">Greensand</a> <a href="Ridge%20%28geology%29">Ridge</a> 9 miles (14.4 km) north of <a href="Ashford%2C%20Kent">Ashford</a> and stretches three miles south into a lower plain towards the <a href="West%20Stour%2C%20Kent">West Stour</a>. The parish is a relatively <a href="dispersed%20settlement">scattered rural one</a>; the settlement of <a href="Stonebridge%20Green">Stonebridge Green</a>, adjacent to Egerton village centre, is also in the parish.
Geography.
A narrow <a href="escarpment">escarpment</a> of dense <a href="Greensand%20%28geology%29">Greensand</a> forms the north of the parish where the largest single residential area is. The <a href="Greensand%20Way">Greensand Way</a> runs in part through the churchyard of St James's Church in the village.
The northern slopes of this are two named woods. Most of the slopes and plain below to the south is used for mixed farming and hedgerows, with a lower proportion of woodland and wider <a href="buffer%20zone">buffer areas</a> between settled farmstead clusters of homes.
The ecclesiastical parish and civil parish overlap.
Amenities.
A large <a href="pub">pub</a>-restaurant, "The Barrow House" (previously The George), is joined by the village's <a href="community%20centre">community centre</a> the Millennium Hall, the village store and post office, a games barn, <a href="cricket">cricket</a> and <a href="association%20football">football</a> pitches, an <a href="internet%20caf%C3%A9">internet café</a>, and a <a href="primary%20school">primary school</a>, which has a minimum weekly event and funding from the local Church of England community. A farmers' market is held weekly in the Millennium Hall.
Egerton has a medium proportion of <a href="Listed%20Building">listed properties</a> for the English countryside such as Egerton House and a <a href="tumulus">Saxon Burial mound</a>.
The 13th-century parish <a href="Church%20%28building%29">church</a> in the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a> exists which is dedicated to the disciple of <a href="Jesus%20Christ">Jesus of Nazareth</a>, <a href="James%2C%20son%20of%20Zebedee">Saint James</a>. It has the highest grading in the national scheme of <a href="listed%20building">listed building</a>s, Grade I.
In film, the media and literature.
The village's now defunct bakery was featured on the 1990s <a href="television">television</a> programme "<a href="The%20Darling%20Buds%20of%20May%20%28TV%20series%29">The Darling Buds of May</a>".
